Documentation

Complete guide to get started with Starter UI template

Contents

  • Introduction
  • Installation
  • Project Structure
  • Customization
  • Components
  • Translations
  • Deployment
  • Pro tips
  • Credits & support

Introduction

What is Starter UI?

Starter UI is a base template for creating fast, modern and easy-to-maintain websites with Astro. It includes a collection of ready-to-use components (headers, heroes, testimonials, footers, etc.) and a clear structure so you can start building without wasting time.

Objective

The goal of Starter UI is to let you create a professional website in hours, not days, with clean and coherent code. It's designed for developers, designers and agencies who want to focus on content and design, not initial setup.

Technologies

  • Astro as main static generator
  • CSS with custom properties (global design tokens)
  • No heavy framework dependencies
  • Full compatibility with Markdown and MDX

What it includes

  • SEO-optimized base structure
  • Reusable and responsive components
  • Customizable color palette and typography
  • Translation system (ES/EN)
  • Documentation and examples ready to copy and paste

Before starting

You only need to have Node 18+ installed and a package manager like npm or pnpm. Once you clone the project, you'll be ready to develop from minute one.

Installation

Prerequisites

Make sure you have installed:

  • Node.js 18 o superior
  • npm o pnpm

Check your version with:

node -v
npm -v

Clone the project

Copy the repository to your computer:

git clone https://github.com/tu-usuario/starter-ui.git
cd starter-ui

Install dependencies

Run in the project root:

npm install

Start development server

Start Astro in development mode:

npm run dev

Then open: http://localhost:4321

There you'll see the template working with automatic reload.

Build for production

When you want to compile the site:

npm run build

The result will be in the /dist folder, ready to upload to your hosting or platforms like Vercel, Netlify or GitHub Pages.

Project Structure

Overview

The project is designed so you can move quickly and understand what each part does.

src/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ components/ ‚Üí Reusable components
‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ header/ ‚Üí Headers
‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ hero/ ‚Üí Heroes
‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ services/ ‚Üí Service cards
‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ testimonials/ ‚Üí Testimonials
‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ faq/ ‚Üí FAQ
‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ footer/ ‚Üí Footers
‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ ...
‚îÇ
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ layouts/ ‚Üí Base templates (BaseLayout, ComponentsLayout‚Ä¶)
‚îÇ
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ pages/ ‚Üí Main pages
‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ index.astro ‚Üí Home
‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ [lang]/ ‚Üí Language versions (es/en)
‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ ...
‚îÇ
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ styles/ ‚Üí Global styles
‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ tokens.css ‚Üí Color, typography and spacing variables
‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ globals.css ‚Üí Global rules
‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ main.css ‚Üí Main file
‚îÇ
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ i18n/ ‚Üí JSON translations (es.json / en.json)

Recommendations

  • Each component should have its own CSS.
  • Colors and sizes should come from tokens.css.
  • Avoid duplicating styles, import globals when possible.
  • If you change language or structure, always do it from /[lang]/... to maintain order.

Customization

The Starter UI template is designed so you can adapt it to your style without breaking the base design. Everything is organized with CSS variables (tokens) and well-structured files that allow you to easily change colors, typography and spacing.

Colors

All system colors are in src/styles/tokens.css.

There you can change values like --color-primary, --color-secondary, --color-bg or --color-text.

For example, if you want the primary color to be blue, just edit that variable and the entire website will use that tone.

Typography

In the same file you can also change the font family and sizes: --font-family-base, --font-size-base, --font-size-h1, etc.

This allows you to unify the text style across the entire website without editing component by component.

Spacing and radius

Distances (margins, paddings, gaps‚Ä¶) and rounded corners also use tokens, like --space-1, --space-8 or --radius-lg.

If you increase or reduce these values, all components maintain coherent proportions.

Override styles per component

Each block (hero, about, footer‚Ä¶) has its own CSS file within its folder, for example:

src/components/hero/simple-centered/Hero.css

There you can adjust styles without affecting other components. It's ideal if you only want to modify something specific.

Custom global styles

If you want to apply general rules (for example, change the scroll or body background), do it in src/styles/globals.css.

There you can add your own classes or global adjustments, without touching the base components.

Final tip

Use tokens whenever possible. They maintain visual coherence and allow you to change the entire site's style by modifying just a few lines.

Components

Starter UI includes a collection of ready-to-use components, designed to maintain a clean and professional aesthetic. They are organized by type within the src/components/ folder.

Component structure

Each component has its own folder with its .astro file and independent CSS.

Example:

src/components/hero/simple-centered/SimpleCentered.astro
src/components/hero/simple-centered/SimpleCentered.css

This allows editing, replacing or duplicating components without affecting the rest of the system.

Types of included components

  • Headers: different types of headers (basic, centered, with login, mega menu).
  • Heroes: versions with background, split, minimalist, or with carousel.
  • About: presentation sections with image and text.
  • Services: cards and grids to display services or features.
  • Testimonials: mosaic or grid designs.
  • FAQ: dropdown lists or minimalist layouts.
  • CTA (Call to Action): sections with buttons and key messages.
  • Footers: versions with columns, CTA or newsletter.

How to use them

In any .astro page, import the component and add it to the layout:

---
import HeaderMega from '../components/header/header-mega/Header.astro';
import SimpleCentered from '../components/hero/simple-centered/SimpleCentered.astro';
---
<HeaderMega />
<SimpleCentered />

Quick customization

Each component uses system variables (--color-primary, --radius-lg, --space-4‚Ä¶), so maintaining visual coherence is automatic. You can see all available variables on the Global Styles page.

If you need something unique, you can duplicate the component, rename it and edit only its CSS or internal content.

Tip

Start building pages by combining existing sections. When you need something different, create a copy and adjust only what's necessary. This way your site stays organized, lightweight and easy to maintain.

Translations (i18n)

Starter UI includes multi-language support through a simple and scalable i18n (internationalization) system.

How it works

Each language has its own JSON file within the src/i18n/ folder.

For example: src/i18n/es.json (Spanish) and src/i18n/en.json (English).

Within those files you define the keys and their translations, for example:

{ "header": { "home": "Home", "components": "Components", "docs": "Documentation" } }

Language routes

Each page has a localized version within the src/pages/[lang]/ folder.

For example: /es/docs or /en/docs.

Astro automatically generates routes with getStaticPaths(), going through the languages defined in LOCALES.

How to use translations in a page

Within any .astro page you import the helper and use it like this:

import { loadT } from '../../i18n';<br>const t = await loadT(lang);<br>{t('header.docs')}

This way you avoid duplicating HTML: you only change the text according to the active language.

Language detection

The language is determined by the URL prefix (/es/, /en/). If there is no prefix, you can configure a default language (for example, Spanish).

Language switching

The header toggle button automatically changes the prefix in the URL and reloads the same page in the selected language.

Tip

Start with one language (for example, Spanish) and add the others when the content is stable. Don't translate everything from the beginning: first validate the design and main sections.

Deployment

Starter UI generates static files, so you can host it on any modern platform.

Vercel

  • Connect your repository, Vercel auto-detects Astro.
  • Command: npm run build
  • Output folder: dist

Netlify

  • Import your repo from Git.
  • Build: npm run build
  • Public: dist

GitHub Pages

Run npm run build and upload the dist folder to gh-pages.

Cloudflare Pages

  • Connect your repo, use npm run build
  • Output dist

Tip

Use Vercel if you want the fastest, zero-config option.

Pro tips

If you want to get the most out of Starter UI and work like a pro, here are some practical tips:

1. Start clean

Don‚Äôt copy an entire component directly. Duplicate only what you need and remove what you don‚Äôt use. This keeps your project lightweight and clear.

2. Use tokens for everything

If you change a color or spacing, always do it in tokens.css. This keeps consistency across the site and lets you redesign in minutes.

3. Reuse layouts

Create base templates (BaseLayout, ComponentsLayout, etc.) to avoid repeating structures. It will save you errors and lines of code.

4. Group your components

If you create new ones, keep them inside organized folders like the originals: hero/, services/, cta/, etc.

5. Avoid inline styles

Use classes or variables. Inline styles break scalability and make dark themes or future redesigns difficult.

6. Build sections before pages

Develop visual blocks (hero, testimonials, cta) and then build pages by combining them. It‚Äôs faster and more flexible.

7. Watch performance

  • Use images in .webp format.
  • Remove unused CSS.
  • Avoid unnecessary dependencies.

8. Prepare your content

Before laying out, have all texts and images ready. This lets you test the real design without reworking blocks later.

9. Design mobile-first

Start from the smallest viewport. Starter UI is built to adapt, but always review details manually.

10. Create your own ‚ÄúPro version‚Äù

Once you master the structure, duplicate the project, rename it and adjust styles. This way, you‚Äôll have your own boilerplate ready for clients or future projects.

Credits & support

Starter UI was created to serve as a solid foundation for developers, designers, and agencies who want to build fast, well-structured sites without complications.

Authorship and acknowledgments

  • Built on Astro, a modern and ultra-fast static site generator.
  • Inspired by professional design systems and scalable component methodologies.
  • Special thanks to the Astro community, MDN, and all open source projects that make this stack possible.

Support & contact

If you find a bug or want to suggest improvements:

  • Open an issue in the project GitHub repository.
  • Or contact directly via support email: hello@starterui.com

License

Starter UI is distributed under the MIT license, which means you can use, modify, and adapt it freely for both personal and commercial projects.

Final tip

Use it as a starting point, not a limit. Adjust styles, create your own components, and turn Starter UI into your personal framework.
